author: {'steamid': '76561198000488097', 'num_games_owned': 575, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 170, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 113, 'last_played': 1405636972}
review:
Well... I really want to recomend it, because it's a really fun game and it has a LOT of potential. BUT it has some improvements to do:
- There are NO MENUS, no start button, no options menu, no exit button, nothing.
- Camera control is awful. Sometimes it will get stuck in a really akward position and you can't see anything.
- A couple of little bugs that are sometimes funny.
So, my review will be like this:
Graphics: 8/10
It's not the BEST GRAPHICS IN THE WORLD. But it's cute and fits well with all the world and game.
Sounds/Music: 7/10
Not the best music ever, it's just there. It's relaxing. And some sounds are... weird. It could be better.
Storyline: 7/10
It's simplistic: the world is getting dry and you have to collect some magic tears to get water. Nothing more than a Super Mario 3D storyline.
Gameplay: 6/10
THIS is where the game has it's worst. Why? You can't control the camera, and, knowing that it's buggy, well, that's awful. Controls are simple, Shift to run, Space to jump, WASD or arrow keys to move. The possibility to control the camera would make this an 8. Or at least, fixing how the camera works will make it something that isn't really necessary so it would be a 7.

Total: 7/10
I'll recomend it. For the price is a bit short (I finished it in 100 minutes, not all the achievements but the storyline), but the creator said that there will be more levels. So, for being it's first game, it's really good.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993063700', 'num_games_owned': 639, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 59, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 59, 'last_played': 1403108743}
review:
Alright so the art style looked pretty cool so I thought I might as well pick it up for ¬£1.50. 

First thing bad is the camera angle, the camera angle will be put in extremely bad places so you can't see where you are going and have to rely on the shadow to know if you are going to fall or not as well as the camera angle not resetting when you die.

It's hard to tell what an enemy is and what isn't and there is only like two enemies that actually really do anything like one enemy just dances and you die if you go near them you also get nothing for killing enemies and would be better just running past them all.

There is also no anti aliasing perhaps that was a problem on my end but I would expect a game released today to at least of anti aliasing.

The 2 player option of playing as Woodle Beaver is the same as playing Tails in Sonic the hedgehog 2. There is no punishment for dying and enemies don‚Äôt appear to attack player 2 and to top it off the camera does not share with player 2 and just focuses on player 1. Perhaps that‚Äôs one of the elements taken from 90‚Äôs games

Not a bad point but just a heads up that a playtime is around 1 hour. 

Overall after completing the game it feels like it's in early beta

I can‚Äôt really complain much since the game only cost ¬£1.50 but this is what I think.

author: {'steamid': '76561198133394101', 'num_games_owned': 1078, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 370, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 370, 'last_played': 1403005072}
review:
I've got a few things to point out, the main one being the fact that I gracefully recomment this wonderful game for all platformer-games enthusiasts out there! Not only does it bring back the ideas and art development of old-school platformer games, the best games of some people's childhood or simply pleasure and destressing times for any person (which are all, of course, pleasant memories for every gamer), but it also has an individual way of becoming remarcable, intriguing the gamers to give it a try. 
The story is not too complicated, it's rebellious against reality - which, after all, is the best thing about old school games...they take you to a new world, apart from reality. This game's world is very colourful, exciting and can be quite challenging sometimes.

I also have a strong point to send across the people who gave negative feedback, making complains that don't really follow accross to be agreeable on. For example, I noticed many complain about the camera mode not being able to control. Well, think about it please, if the base idea of the game is to keep it simple and to the point, why would you want the "easy" tasks to be extremely easy too? I say the camera mode, along with other tricky details, are what really make the challenge of the gameplay be actually challenging. The opposition of these details are what really give the game the perfect ballance - it's not too easy, but nor too hard. That ballance is what makes the game fun.
I respect each gamer's opinion, positive or negative, but if you don't like these game genres or simply don't have the patience to take on the challenge of the game, why do you play? It's a shame to insult someone's work for no real valid reason.

As all's been said, once again, I think if you're looking for a relaxing fun game and enjoy adventures, this is a great game for you!

author: {'steamid': '76561197986617621', 'num_games_owned': 13948, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 70, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 70, 'last_played': 1403244697}
review:
Single Player:  In single player mode, Woodle is a very basic game in concept and execution. For a low enough price, it's an OK one player game. It would appear as though it's made for children, but some of the gaps are unforgiving, and often if you fall, you'll have to start back at the beginning of a level. What makes the game hard (and hard to recommend) is the frequent camera problems...it's the games weak point. The camera shifts are often unclear and leave much to be desired. It kills the enjoyment of a simplistic "kids" game, but it's not a bad game. The camera gets crazy sometimes in single player, but if you are thinking that the multiplayer is of interest to you, do not get this game...

Multiplayer: Of course the co-op is a new feature which was added later, but the camera works just like a 1 player game. Focus on the first player. Player two will find him/herself lost, off the screen trying to get back. (With the XBox controller, you can press "Start" and respawn relatively near the first player...but you might get stuck in a "cliff loop" where you just keep falling and falling until player one moves far away from an edge.

Overall: The game is a pass for everyone...unless you have a child that you DO NOT like and want to give the game to in order to anger them with terrible camera work, and unforgiving respawns. 

We uninstalled after about 30 minutes.  (EDIT: Now that it has cards, I have to let the game idle to get them.)

---------
Camera Fix on the way???
I did see that the Developer claims that there is an update on the way in response to someone else complaining about the camera problems. The Developer comment is here:  http://steamcommunity.com/app/299460/discussions/0/522729358902017525/?insideModal=1#c522729359205413263

author: {'steamid': '76561197998413285', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 96, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 96, 'last_played': 1402462602}
review: Okay let me start with this, Anyone who gave this a thu,bs down missed the point. This is not some master piece of a game, the people who made it KNOW it has mistakes, it is just a small show of what a handful of people can do in a small amount of time. The game is $3 and $2 when on sale (Sometimes even $1.50) So the way this should be viewed is that you are donating the money for the group to one day make a game they can be proud of. If Woodle had a large group working on it then I think it would be like any simple platformer without the flaws, a cute style and a cute character. So you all know the multiplayer is LAN only, and the game takes about 45 minutes to an hour to beat. Remember though, those who thumbed this little guy down mised the point, only buy this game if you love trees, or you wanna support the small crew and give them motavation to take on bigger projects.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980199331', 'num_games_owned': 3533, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 52, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17, 'last_played': 1416305367}
review:
Juste comme √ßa, entre vous et moi : cette review est dat√©e du 10 juin 2014. C'est important. Du moins j'esp√®re.

√Ä l'heure actuelle, Woodle Tree Adventures a du potentiel. Et malheureusement, c'est tout.
Tout d'abord, si vous √™tes un adulte, je ne suis pas certain que le jeu vous plaira. Comme le montrent les screenshots et le trailer, le jeu est clairement orient√© enfants, et rien ne d√©ment cette impression.
C'est ennuyeusement court, tout d'abord. Tous ceux qui l'ont termin√© indiquent une dur√©e de vie d'environ une heure. Du moins √ßa, c'est avec des r√©flexes et un background d'adulte. Il y a fort √† parier qu'il en irait autrement pour un enfant.
Ensuite, c'est laborieux. Des checkpoints qui fonctionnent de mani√®re tout √† fait biscornue et sans le moindre cue visuel/audio - quand seulement checkpoint il y a, une allonge ridiculement courte pour le personnage, des contr√¥les √©trangement choisis √† la manette (A pour sauter OK, X pour courir d'accord, mais B POUR FRAPPER ? Je veux dire, quand on a un minimum de logique on met le bouton pour frapper et le bouton pour courir dans une configuration o√π les deux peuvent √™tre utilis√©s en m√™me temps - voire les trois. Frapper en plein saut apr√®s avoir pris de l'√©lan, non ? Vraiment ?), un manque d'animations flagrants, des textures carr√©ment manquantes par endroits, une cam√©ra √† tout le moins capricieuse, voil√† pour le plus gros des √©normes d√©fauts du jeu.
Au nombre des qualit√©s : le look minimaliste peut plaire. Pas ma tasse de th√©, mais j'en conviens ais√©ment. La musique est ent√™tante sans pour autant prendre la t√™te.
Et c'est √† peu pr√®s tout.

Alors, recommandable ? Peut-√™tre comme investissement √† moyen terme. Mais si vous cherchez du fun imm√©diat... Non. Passez votre chemin.
Et voil√† pourquoi cette review est dat√©e : si le d√©veloppeur fait grandir son b√©b√©, il pourrait en sortir quelque chose de bien. Le temps nous le dira. Dans tous les cas, le prix n'est pas exactement obsc√®ne, donc √† vous de voir.

author: {'steamid': '76561198093524220', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 168, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 135, 'last_played': 1562119367}
review: I think this game is awesome, but it requires a lot of minor and major fixes. First of all, there is no "health" bar, so whenever you TOUCH a monster you have to restart at the last checkpoint. Second of all, these checkpoints aren't marked so you cannot tell if you made it to a checkpoint or not. You also cannot move around your POV so it's always stuck at default. Because of this, your body is sometimes (most of the time) blocked by something, or it is hard to see yourself in a comfortable way. I hope that this game soon gets updated because it would bring SO much more attention to it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022997080', 'num_games_owned': 2142, 'num_reviews': 388, 'playtime_forever': 92, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 92, 'last_played': 1402965001}
review:
I wish I had something good to say about Woodle Tree Adventures. It's colorful art style brings back fond memories of classic 3D platformers, which much to my dismay have all but disappeared from gaming in recent years. As much as I wanted to love Woodle, as a game it's among the worst designed, most disappointing experiences I've had in a very long time. It took only an hour of my time to complete, but it felt like so much more with how depressing those sixty minutes were.

Woodle Tree is a very traditional collectathon platformer on paper; traverse levels picking up inane objects to bring back a spirit tree that's grown sad over the disappearing water of the world. Upon actually playing the game, everything instantly loses its enticing charm, reduced to a lesson in how to completely ruin a genre that I hold especially close to my heart.

At the forefront of all these problems is the games camera, which for reasons I cannot understand was chosen to be fixed in place, presumably moving with you and positioning itself as to best allow you to get through levels. This is a bad idea for more reasons than I care to list, the biggest being that it makes judging the distance for jumps incredibly difficult, not to mention caused me an extreme amount of motion sickness (something I've never experience in a game). Levels are designed with a noticeable lack in direction, full of pointless dead ends, oddly position platforms, and invisible checkpoints that neither tell you when you reach them or work as intended much of the time.

The sound design is just sad to have to listen to, with awful sound effects and a soundtrack that is chaotic, perhaps even musically offensive. The cute art design is the only thing I can give scant amounts of praise to, but even that loses its charm when it jumps radically between styles, none of which are particularly interesting to look at or even reflect the lighthearted feel the game seems to be going for.

I'd like to say Woodle Tree Adventures isn't one of the most dismal games I've played recently, but there is nothing I can even partially recommend it for, and wish I'd headed the words of others and passed on it myself. It left me feeling hollow, and sad for the developer who almost seemed to have something at a point before it slipped through his fingers. 

It's really no wonder the spirit tree is crying. I would too if I was stuck in this game any longer than I was.

[b]You can read more of my writing on [url=http://kritiqal.com/2014/06/09/woodle-tree-adventures-review/]Kritiqal[/url].[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198042937558', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 38, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 37, 'last_played': 1455853475}
review: This is by far the best game that I have ever played. I would give 10 baby trees out of 10 any day. For anyone desperate for a game to play for the next 10,000 hours, I would highly suggest this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051754194', 'num_games_owned': 449, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 126, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1403210619}
review:
If you're looking for a really-challenging videogame for platform experts, Woodle Tree Adventures is probably not adequate for you. Anyhow, this indie game from Italy has its own notable strenghts: 

- beautiful to look at, with its charming graphics and very cute places and character design
- definetly relaxing
- filled with very good original music
- nice ideas and mechanics (Woodle's sack, the different weapon/leafs...)

I think it is the perfect game if you have little children who start to play videogames. On the contrary, as you can see from many reviews (and also from this one), it can be pleasant also for adults.  

I would suggest difficulty levels (Woodle moving faster, stronger enemies, maybe boss battles...); by the way, the game is already good for what it is. 

For the creator keeping up the good work, it's an 8/10 for me!

author: {'steamid': '76561197968587121', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 161, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 85, 'last_played': 1403414844}
review:
Woodle Tree Adventures is the absolute definition of the word: 'Adorable'. This cute, fun little game gets you addicted to collecting Berries and Water Drops rather quickly, with some challenge involved. The levels are enormous and will take a good 20 mins or longer to complete each one, ranging from Snow to a Honeycomb Design. I love this game for the time that I played it, and I do hope the developers add more content like Levels and Boss Battles. The enemies are just really obstacles in the way, and can be taken down in just a one hit swipe from your leaf (which can be upgraded).

Overall I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a good platformer fix, and if you happen to be in a down mood. Woodle Tree Adventures will surely help to cheer you up :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198006358997', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 207, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 81, 'last_played': 1417564507}
review:
Em Woodle Tree Adventure, jogamos com um pequeno tronco de arvore que deve percorrer 7 mundos tem√°ticos atr√°s das l√°grimas de fada, um item m√°gico que permite resgatar a √°gua em sua terra natal.

Trazendo a cl√°ssica mec√¢nica dos t√≠tulos de plataforma tridimensionais, temos um jogo que exige do jogador a pulos precisos ou mesmo tempo que o fornece controles simplificados. Os visuais s√£o simples, por√©m extremamente carism√°ticos, fazendo uma mistura curiosa de Bomberman 64 e a Hora da Aventura. 

Entretanto o jogo conta com alguns defeitos, sendo um deles a curt√≠ssima campanha que n√£o chega a durar 2horas (100% das conquistas) e o modo multi jogador mal trabalhado, que n√£o s√≥ impede partidas via internet como exige DOIS controles de Xbox 360 para funcionar localmente.

Em suma √© um jogo simples e curto, mas que por seu carisma e simplicidade acaba valendo os R$4,40 atualmente cobrados por ele.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989346754', 'num_games_owned': 406, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 42, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 37, 'last_played': 1403921389}
review:
This could be a much better game.  The graphics are charming, the soundtrack is nicely chill and the lack of stuff like time limits is quite nice.  It's got serious potential, but a few negative aspects really work against that potential.

The first and most damaging is the fact that you cannot control the camera.  In a 3D platformer where it's very easy to mis-time your jumps, that's a quick road to frustration.  Even worse, sometimes the game will change your camera angle for you, making it hard to see a jump that a moment before was perfectly visible.  Add in the fact that if the character's pack is full it enlarges so much sometimes that you have trouble seeing past it and you can see that earlier potential just start to bleed away in a flurry of missed jumps.

The second flaw doesn't directly affect gameplay, but it affects immersion a lot.  That is, the character animation.  For the most part this is fine, and I really do like little touches like being able to jump until Woodle is upside-down.  Charming.  But when walking about the world, I noticed very quick that the walk animation doesn't interact at all with the ground.  The speed at which you move seems independant of the motion of the legs, giving a feel of sliding about which may not seem like a lot but since you have to look at this for the entire game, it gets a bit bothersome.  And to a degree, since you can't really tell speed from watching the character, sometimes it's hard to judge jumps and you're down into the abyss again.

The third is the general lack of explanation of anything.  I've played up to where I was able to buy a second leaf mainly by accident.  I had no idea why I was supposed to gather fruits until I pretty much randomly wandered outside the house for a bit.  I'm not really sure what it does yet, since there's no explanation when you get it, so I guess trial and error?  In any case, the game doesn't really give you anything to tell you that upgrading your leaf is significant, so it almost feels like the game doesn't care.  Even a little fanfare would be nice.

Overall, I'd say maybe a 6.5/10.  Barely recommend, mainly based on the remaining charm and the knowledge that updates seem to be planned.  Hopefully they'll fix some of these issues.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080435169', 'num_games_owned': 1907, 'num_reviews': 277, 'playtime_forever': 202, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 181, 'last_played': 1405533380}
review:
Editing the entire review
apparently people *think* that if they vote down my review it wont matter and they would be helping this game which i really think the dev just made other users to vote down reviews because they want this to sell for some reason

Woodle Tree adventures is a game that should not be in steam at all
The game is so far broken i mean .... i cant even play it without raging 

For kids ? NOPE dont even think about it, if a 10 year old kid plays this would rage so much probably gonna break everything around.

What iS bad 

There is no camera controls you just keep dying
The animation is horrible 

The soundtrack is VERY horrible in the water level it just sounds like a rookie using MIDI for the first time and just spams it.

The game story ends like nobody's business no idea what the hell happened when i finished it
You will die so much because of the poor animation and camera controls

the game is not even finished it feels NOT finished there is no Options or an actual menu.
When you die and respawn they did not set that right sometimes i die and respawn at the beginning and sometimes the game even pushes me farther to places i never reached

you can see Berries on some levels that you cant reach (AKA) Work in progress.
There are a lot of stuff that looks undone in the game and was not even deleted

Encountered several bugs and even tho the devs said they updated i dont feel anything have changed at all ...

Yeah sure vote this review because you think this game look good SURE its your choice. go buy it 
IT does not even deserve that price.

A TIP 
This game got Free keys From WGN and Indiegala.
and i still think if i got it for free i would still hate it

I am so very disappointed with this game when i saw it on greenlight i thought hey a new game for me to play with that is a 3d platform with an adorable look, little did i know it would be a complete failure.

if you noticed i did not say  " Pros " In this game because i found non

author: {'steamid': '76561198005403986', 'num_games_owned': 2599, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 201, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1411633373}
review:
While this game could have been an entertaining simplistic platformer, it is instead a poorly realized shell of it's own idea.
It is incredibly short, the story is non existant. All the UI elements are disjointed and look out of place and poorly aligned.
The controls are slippery and the actual platforming is ruined by static camera angles that are often non responsive. [ie; they get stuck at previous angles and don't update/adjust to the new setting]
There are enemies, but, you're fighting the camera more often.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984214000', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 82, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 82, 'last_played': 1402155307}
review:
A cheap, low-effort, unpolished platformer.  Includes six levels for you to platform around, with the main goal being to collect three tears in a level before you can exit and progress to the next level.  Other collectibles include berries, which have only two uses: unlocking achievements and buying optional weapon upgrades.  The former are useless, the latter are only debatably useful, as many enemies are easily avoidable, and in a worse case easy to dispatch with your default weapon.  To make matters worse, there are three tiers of weapon upgrades you can get.  The first one lets your leaf fire a projectile (to make dispatching the already easily avoidable enemies trivial).  The second and third?  A simple color change, and a different particle effect for the projectile you shoot.  Not worth the effort to farm the berries for them.  Because of this, the game doesn't give you much motivation to actually collect any of the (non-required) collectibles.

From a gameplay perspective, the platforming isn't very tight.  Controls are often loose and slippery, which can lead to many frustrating deaths.  These deaths are made all the more frustrating with an inconsistent "checkpoint" system implemented in the game that randomly decides to respawn you in a fair location close to where you died, or at the start of the level.  However, once you get adjusted to this, the platforming just tends to be easy and...boring.  Even the enemies in the game present no challenge, often standing still and waiting for you to kill them.  There are maybe a half dozen enemies in the game total that provide a greater challenge of...moving in a line.  Literally one enemy in the game fires projectiles.  None of which are hard to deal with (except for the last one, which is elaborated on below).  The game does include a local co-op mode, but I fail to see a point to it, as (at least in the hub world) the second player is almost exclusively tied to the first player as the camera is locked on that player, leaving no extra incentives bring a second player as that player can't even help you explore and complete the level more quickly.

From a presentation perspective, the game looks cheap: almost every object is a simple mashup of a basic 3D construct, a cube, a cylinder, or a cone, scaled to give the illusion of a more complex object.  Animations, where they exist, are usually basic looping idle, or walking animations where the models in question simply waggle their arms or legs about.  Enemies, when dispatched, often simply fall over and just...vanish.  Sometimes with a poof of (barely recognizable) smoke, and sometimes with an extra sound effect.  Textures are simplistic, often including no detail.  One shining example of this lack of detail are the levels that include a snow effect, where the snow is represented by...an extra white, untextured cube stacked on top of other level geometry.  Finally, there are some very strange camera positioning choices in the game, and since the game doesn't let you adjust your camera angle or position, can make some sections more difficult than they need to be.  Finally, the music and sound effects in the game are completely unremarkable, with the end-of-level jingle being a recording of someone mashing an out-of-tune piano.

The game is also buggy.  Bugs encountered during my playthrough include: being pushed through the level geometry to my death by a moving platform, enemies that fire projectiles continuing to fire projectiles even after being killed, jumping up against the corner of certain geometry in the level causing the player character to flip upside down and become stuck, random white square appearing on the screen in the hub world (I assume these are meant to be dialog boxes of some kind, but don't display properly), camera angles often not correcting themselves when moving through a level, or after a death, and on rare occasions sticking in the pre-level cutscene position when you enter a level, rendering it unbeatable (since you can't see where your character is).  The worst offender though: the number of fruit you collect from a level doesn't reset when you exit a level unless you reset the game.  This allows you to enter a level, collect a ton of fruit, exit the level (which adds it to the total necessary for unlocking the achievements and the unlockable weapons), then re-enter the level and immediately exit to add the same amount of fruit to your total again.  You can do this non-stop to unlock all of the collectibles in the game, without even going past the first level.

My final thoughts: I feel like this game was the end result of a single developer new to developing video games.  The credits back me up on this, as many of the roles listed were done by the same person, with one exception besides the special thanks section.  If I take that into account, I encourage that developer to keep writing new games, as they're moving in a step in the right direction.  But I encourage them, for future titles, to remember to make the gamplay engaging and rewarding, to make smarter game design choices in terms of controls and presentation, and to spend some extra time polishing the game and stomping out bugs.  I also recommend not trying to compare your games to, frankly superior games (such as Super Mario 64 and Banjo Kazooie, which this game was compared to), when the only similarities are you can jump and collect things.

Only buy Woodle Tree Adventures if you desperately want to waste 30-60 minutes of your life, and you have literally nothing better to spend $3 on.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001088727', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 61, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19, 'last_played': 1403129278}
review:
A collect-a-thon game with a cute woodland theme? This must be just like Banjo Kazooie, right?

No, no not really.

Let me explain. The main problem, the single most important reason I did not enjoy this game is because the act of collecting was not fun. Banjo Kazooie nails this down perfectly with a wide variety of things to do and collect, with different missions you need to complete in each level that utilize characters and the environment to keep things interesting. Woodle Tree Adventures doesn't have any of this. There are lots of little problems (which I'll go into in a moment), but this fundamental flaw is what keeps this game from being a must-play.

To put it kindly...this feels like it would be an amazing game on the Ouya, both in scope of gameplay and graphical quality. The sound assets are boring and repetitive, UI is amateurish, the textures are rough, enemy design feels poor...speaking of those enemies, depth perception is a major problem for me in this game. It often throws off jumps, but more annoyingly, makes it difficult to figure out where an enemy is in relation to myself, meaning I often found myself running into them trying to hit them with the leaf and got sent back to the start of the level. This is also exacerbated by the fact that there is no camera control, often with some very poorly chosen stock angles.

Is there a checkpoint system? There's certainly no visual cue for such, though near the end there's a series of jumps made difficult by the depth perception problem, and falling off that a few times I got sent only back to the middle of the stage, not the beginning. No idea if only falling checkpoints you or dying to enemies at that point would have worked, but I certainly never saw anything that looked like a checkpoint. 

There's also the matter of abilities. Games like Banjo Kazooie or Mario 64 have lots of things you can do with different combinations of inputs, as well as power-ups. This game has jump, run, and hit, and the animations for all of these are pretty boring. The rucksack, which seems like a really cool idea, quickly wears out its welcome with the sheer size it grows to.

All in all, this feel like someone's first game project where they said "I want to make a new Banjo Kazooie," but didn't understand what makes that game great in the first place. If you've read everything I've said and think to yourself "yeah, I could put up with all that," it's currently 30% off for a total price of $2.09. If you don't mind the poor design and just want your collecting fix on PC, there are worse ways to spend your money. I would recommend it...with some [i]very[/i] heavy caveats.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075234627', 'num_games_owned': 1012, 'num_reviews': 354, 'playtime_forever': 133, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 37, 'last_played': 1459125205}
review:
Took me 35 minutes to beat, way too short of a game. Controls arent great, granted there are worse. The camera needs work. You can only get an overview of the level when it starts, pretty annoying. I experienced tearing and uneven framerates on my GTX770, feels like it could use some optimization. There is no explanation given why you should collect the berries, at least not that I could see. Not a single achievement unlocked for me, despite beating the game.

For the low price I shouldnt complain really, but I feel it is too short to justify buying.

Music was nice and relaxing tho, that weighs up many of the games flaws. The chord when you beat a level feels out of place however.

author: {'steamid': '76561198130358670', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 142, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 97, 'last_played': 1404241388}
review:
The Good:

* The graphics are smooth, cute and overall nice to look at. Reminds me of kirby (the graphics, not the game.)
* The music fits well with the game
* It's charming in its simplicity

The Bad:

* Can be a little frustrating at times with the jumping but overall not challenging
* No boss battles and uninspired enemies
* Extremly short. The "worlds" are more like "stages" and there's only 6 of them. I beat the game I think in less than 2 hours. 

Even at the small asking price, it's hard for me to recommend this game to anyone over the age of 10.  It needs more work. I'd rather pay a higher price for a better game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198138461284', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 65, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 65, 'last_played': 1402099723}
review:
At first i saw this game for $2 and thought "why not?" Boy was i sure surprised at the grand adventure this game brought to the table, it begins with a tree asexually reproducing a tiny little nugget, which turns out to be you character. i had plenty of fun controlling he little woodland testiclefor the duration it took to beat the game (not very long). Nonetheless when i beat it, it was the most productive thing i have done all day, consiering i didnt leave bed till noon

10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197994883802', 'num_games_owned': 1492, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 54, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19, 'last_played': 1403176286}
review:
When i saw this on Greenlight i was waiting for this like for a good platform game. Cool, simply and sweet graphics in 3D with open levels to explore.

But when i got this today and installed...
It's not that what i expected. Game have no sense; there is no special story, gameplay is so much boring, level constructions sucks, sound effects are bad, enemies are nothing, animation sucks... I can find more problems in this game. Only one thing is good here- graphics, but this is not enought.

This game just sucks. If u want a good platformer- don't try/buy this. I didn't played this for long time, but i can't do it anymore. It's too bad.

I'm only happy that i didn't waste money on this. I again just got raped by "free game from voting"...
